results.title: Chicago transport: a case study
results.brief_description: “Summary: part of chicago’s transport system is formed by A Radial Network of Expressways. Besides increased accessibility these expressways have made an impact on surrounding land values and land use. the implications of this are discussed by the commissioner of public works for Chicago and the vice-chairman of the Chicago planning commission. the film compares the effects of two particular expressways (the john f. Kennedy and the edens) and then focuses on a new development along one of them- the edens plaza shopping precinct. introduced by dr. john blunden”

results.title: Chicago now: the better to see you
results.brief_description: An informal look at the city of Chicago. This photographic tour is hosted by some of the people who live in Chicago, and they talk about their favourite places in the city. The program gives a new insight into one of America’s largest cities

results.title: Chicago blues
results.creator_credit: Irit Film Production and Harley Cokeliss
results.brief_description: Provides an account of the evolution of blues music from its origins in the rural south of America to the contemporary electric sound shaped in the ghettos of Chicago. The harsh experiences of blacks in America and the liberation they found through music are delineated through archival footage, interviews and performances by musicians at home or in Southside clubs. Features amongst others, Muddy Waters, Junior Wells, Floyd Jones, J.B.Hutto and Dick Gregory. This film is suitable for tertiary levels.

results.title: Chicago's modern architecture
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Egons Tomsons and George Barford
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at Chicago’s modern architecture. Covers the Chicago school, modernism and post-modernism and shows the way in which the post modernists attempt to revive classical architectural features. Includes works by Sullivan, Richardson, Wright, Burnham and Root, Jeny, Van der Rohe, Yamasaki and Elmut Jahn.

results.title: Chicago
results.creator_credit: Miramax Films, Martin Richards and Rob Marshall
results.brief_description: A dazzling spectacle that glides between the intrigue of rivalry and betrayal to sensational fantasies of music and dance! At a time when crimes of passion result in celebrity headlines, nightclub sensation Velma Kelley and spotlight-seeking Roxie Hart find themselves sharing space on Chicago’s famed Murderess Row. Velma and Roxie will stop at nothing to outdo each other in their obsessive pursuit of fame and celebrity. Stars Rene Zellweger, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Richard Gere with Queen Latifah, John C. Reilly, Lucy Liu. Dion Beebe is director of photography. Based on the musical play Chicago, directed and choreographed for the stage by Bob Fosse; based on the play by Maurine Dallas Watkins. (Awards: Winner of several awards including Winner of 2003 Academy Awards for Best Motion Picture of the Year; Winner of 2003 BAFTA Film Awards for Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role: Catherine Zeta-Jones; Winner of 2003 Golden Globes Awards for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy)

results.title: Chiapas Army Base occupation (Mexico) Jan 1, 2001
results.brief_description: This astounding testimony to ‘the power of the people’ was given to the Memory Grid Community Collection as part of the SKA TV video compile ‘Global Insights 4’, a collection of shorts from around the world with a focus on grass-roots peoples’ action. Chiapas Army Base (Mexico) was filmed by Big Noise Tactical (USA) a not-for-profit, all-volunteer collective of media-makers around the world, ‘dedicated to circulating beautiful, passionate, revolutionary images.’

results.title: Chiang Mai: northern capital
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, John Morris, Thanom Soongnarata and Brian Hannant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
In Chiang Mai, Thailand’s northern capital, many traditions and crafts have remained unchanged for hundreds of years. This film looks at the native handicrafts, including the production of silver jewellery, lacquerware utensils and silk-weaving. We take part in a colourful festival which marks the end of the Buddhist Lent. Through the day and into the night we see the solemn religious ceremonies, and the carefree carnival, complete with fireworks

results.title: Chi: the breath of life
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Bernice Daly
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
In this episode, Nevill Drury visits the Oki East-West Centre to investigate disciplines which draw on eastern thought and philosophy for new directions in health care. “Chi” is the Chinese word for breath of life, an inner energy. The Chinese believe it is the source of remarkable power, so the ability to control this energy is vital for a healthy and happy life. In a healthy person, the “Chi” flows smoothly, integrating body, mind and spirit, but in an unwell person there are blockages, or imbalances. The techniques demonstrated include Oki Yoga, Tai Chi, Shiatsu (with Bruce Gyngell as the patient), macrobiotics and acupuncture.

results.title: Cheyenne autumn
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Bernard Smith and John Ford
results.brief_description: This is the last and perhaps best Western directed by John Ford, featuring a stellar cast including Richard Widmark, Karl Malden, Sal Mineo, Edward G. Robinson and James Stewart as the light-hearted, quick-fingered Wyatt Earp. A small band of Cheyenne Indians attempt to escape from their barren Oklahoma reservation, over 1,500 treacherous miles to their own lush Wyoming lands, from which they were transported after surrendering to the army in 1877. Nominated for an Academy Award for Best Colour Cinematography, this is a beautiful and powerful film that stunningly combines a profound and passionate story of the mistreatment of American Indians with some of the most magnificent and energetic Western lore ever put to the screen.
